utterances: And just a word.
You were playing the opening passage of my favorite jazz record, ""West End Blues."" That would follow the Caruso, say.
And see what you heard, what the audience heard, was his horn and his voice as one.
You couldn't tell anymore where his voice began or his horn left off, and that's part of the essence of a genius on his instrument and himself, a part of him.
What was the first kind of music that you fell in love with, like when you were a young person, before you had this radio show?
Oh, gosh, I don't know.
It might have been even--it might have been, (Singing) `I'm forever blowing bubbles, pretty bubbles in the air,' a popular song of the era.
Yeah.
After World War I or during it, something like ""Down The Road To Tipparary."" But I heard--in immigrant homes, I heard Caruso records all...
Yeah.
I say Caruso.
Scratch and awe, even the scratch--because they were scratchy records after a while--even the scratch added to the vividness of the memory...
Yeah.
Yeah.
...to hear that voice.
But then I used to hear blues.
You loved the blues, right?
Now, you see, I was going to the University of Chicago Law School, and I just liked it.
You know, I dreamed of Clarence Darrow and I woke up to Justice Scalia, so it wasn't for me.
So I was a streetcar student.

That is, I would change, because I lived at a hotel near North Side, and so I'd stop off at the Black Belt and change and that's when I heard the blues and spirituals coming through the windows, through the doors of all these shops.
Now there's a difference between the spiritual and the gospel song.
Yeah.
And in the book, Professor Thomas A.
Dorsey--not Tommy Dorsey, Professor Thomas A.
Dorsey--who was once known as Georgia Tom who played the blues for Ma Rainey, who was the teacher of Bessie Smith.
And his wife died and he was saved, religiously saved, and he wrote gospel songs.
Uh-huh.
Gospel songs are of the north.
They followed the Civil War.
They're good news music.
Mahalia's song I first heard was ""Move On Up a Little Higher,"" and it's a voice such as the Welsh would call speciale.
Mary Jo White, the head of the SEC, said the trading halt reinforced the need for Wall Street and regulators to fix technological vulnerabilities in these exchanges.
UNIDENTIFIED ACTOR #4: (As character) You have been defeated.
Well, you know what's interesting about you also is you were just saying that some of the first songs that you loved as a young person were from around World War I.

And yet among the people that you interviewed, and we have some tape from this interview, is someone who was sort of a heroine of my generation, many years later, Janis Joplin, who you interviewed in 1968.
And we have a clip of that tape.
You asked her about her musical influences and here's that tape.
(Soundbite of 1968 interview)
And ...(unintelligible) you mentioned Billie Holiday so apparently then Billie has had an effect on you, too.
Not really as much as people would--people would like to think.
I listen to her a lot, but like, she has--I don't have any of her subtly, the same way that I don't think Aretha Franklin's had much effect on my singing.
Like, Otis Redding had a lot of effect on my singing, but Aretha Franklin is a lot more subtle.
I'm more of a driver than...
The dynamo in the...
Yeah, than the--it's going to take me a few years.
You're more of a blues shouter.
A phrase we used to use years ago is `blues shouter.'
Yeah.
Well, see, I've only been singing, like, really, about two years ago.
I don't have it down yet, that's all.
The sad part about that is she was saying `It's going to take me a few years,' and, of course, she died so young.
She--I remember--she was life at full tide.
Now many of our listeners, this is an old ballroom that was empty, but it was full that night.
And most of those kids were stoned, was half-lit.
They were stoned.
But the one who wasn't stoned, though, she was full of Southern Comfort--a horrible drink, by the way--and so she glistened.
She had so much juice in her.
She came from a rather depressing town, Port Arthur, Texas, oil, but in the midst of all that was this girl, this young woman who had such juice to her.
And this took place before she sang her great one, ""Me & Bobby McGee,"" which has the great lyric of Kris Kristofferson.
I love that lyric, `Freedom's just another word for nothing left to lose.'
Mm-hmm.
You talk about it being a contemporary phrase today the world over, that's it.
Yeah.
But she had that extra juice.
I got to get some callers in here.
I know there's a lot of people that want to talk with you.
If you'd like to join the conversation, the number is (800) 989-8255.
I've been trying to keep Studs Terkel all to myself, but I'm going to let the audience in now.
Jason calling from Muscatine, Louisiana, is it?
Iowa.
Iowa?
OK.
Hi.
Go ahead, Jason.
Well, first I want to say, sir, that it's an honor to find out what exactly you do.
I grew up with grandparents from the Great Depression and parents a little younger than that and I've heard your name in so many contexts and places it's almost been a myth until now.
So it's nice to finally find out what exactly you do.

My question is this--and I'd be more than happy to take the answer off the air--in all the interviews that you've done and people letting you into their lives and then finding out what happened to them before and after, is there a single theme or lesson that you could distill all of their experiences down to?
And thank you very much.
You know, that's--it's a good question, but it's almost impossible to answer.
Each one had something.
There's Peggy Terry, an Appalachian woman, little formal education.
She came here during the '60s when many mountain people came from the South as well as black people, the migration, to work in the mills that were at that time beginning to close.
And Peggy had a way of talking that was just innately poetic, and she was just a natural.
There's the ex-Klan leader, C.P.
Ellis, who belonged to the Klan all his life, but bit by bit by bit, something was happening to him and he became a leading advocate of Martin Luther King at the end.
See, these are two I name.
And Nancy Jefferson, the daughter of a sharecropper, who taught her, as she said--an example in phonics--`You break down the word like you break down cotton.
When you pick cotton, you know, you break it up to fit it in that bag you drag.
And so it was a lesson.
And he was using his work form, the most humble of all, picking cotton, as a way to teach her to speak and break down words.
But there is no one person.
That would be very difficult.
Each one--I'll tell you a very quick story that may help answer the question.
I was interviewing the days of the public housing project being very new and this was a mixed project.
It was about 50 years ago and I can't remember if the woman, anyway, was white or black.
She was light-skinned.
She was very pretty, very skinny and bad teeth because she couldn't afford a dentist.
And about three little kids from about four to six years old are jumping around.
They want to hear Mama's voice on the tape recorder.
And she'd never spoken before on a tape recorder, so I say to the kids, `You be quiet and I'll play you Mama's voice.'
And so she says listening to her voice for the first time in her life, she hears a phrase and she puts her hand over her mouth and she says, `Oh, my God.
And I say, `What is it?
She says, `I never knew I felt that way before.
Well, bingo for me and bingo for her.
That's the kind of stuff that excites me very much.

That's the kind of thing you want to hear when you're an interviewer when you're interviewing somebody, something that you didn't even know you were going for, something you didn't even know you were going to get from a person.
That's right.
And something she didn't even know...
Right.
Exactly.
...she felt.
That's the best kind.
Mr.
Terkel, I recently saw Martin Scorsese's film about Bob Dylan.
I don't know if you saw it, but it made a huge impression on me.
I saw Bob Dylan in a way that I never had before.

He was interviewed now in his present life, and I found the way he spoke and the things he was saying to be so--I don't know--out there, just so different from any kind of conventional artist that I'd ever heard.
And I want you, if you could, to go back to the interviews that you took with him and talk a little bit of your impression when you met him.
All right.
Thanks for that.
And before I get Mr. Terkel to respond, Gail, I'm going to play some tape we have of a Bob Dylan interview that Studs Terkel did back in 1963.
And thanks for your call, Gail.
(Soundbite of 1963 interview)
I saw Woody once, a long, long time ago in Burbank, California, which was when I was just a little boy.
Now I don't even remember seeing him, you know, and I heard him play.
